Risk Stratification in the Event of a Radiology Plain Film Reporting Backlog /19012 / 1.1

There has been an increase in radiology imaging activity both in terms of patient numbers and in terms of complexity and length of time required for reporting the more complex examinations e.g. CT colonography and follow up oncology scans. This combined with addressing diagnostic waiting times and activity (DM01 guidance), MDT requirements and reporting staff vacancy rates has led to demand often exceeding capacity.

Nationwide it is known there is a national shortage of radiologists which has led to significant backlogs of reporting. There is currently an average vacancy rate across all non-specialist acute trusts of 14 per cent (MEHT currently at 25% vacancy). This supports evidence from the Royal College of Radiologists regarding the difficulties in recruiting and retaining radiologists. This leads to delays in x-ray results being shared with clinicians responsible for patient care, or x-rays being examined by clinicians without the necessary specialist training.

It is acknowledged that it is the responsibility of the Radiology Department to ensure appropriate processes are in place for the monitoring and management of a backlog of reporting and to ensure that this is appropriately communicated to stakeholders.

The purpose of this document is to ensure that the MEHT Radiology Department has an agreed and documented protocol in place for reporting turnaround, escalating breaches and monitoring and management of a reporting backlog across all modalities.

data.text: Imaging Services Manager (ISM) and Deputy Imaging services Manager (DISM)
It is the ISM and DISM to ensure the implementation, update and revision of this document in conjunction with the Radiology Governance Lead.
It is the RSM responsibility to ensure appropriate and timely escalation of a backlog concerns to the ISM and DISM for action.

It is the PACS managers' responsibility to ensure that there are daily monitoring checks completed on the backlog figures, that these are adequately surmised for presentation to the accountable officers on a weekly basis. It is also the responsibility of the PACS Manager to ensure there is a trained deputy in place for times of planned/unplanned leave to ensure continuity and adherence to this protocol.

It is the responsibility of Radiologist and Reporting Radiographers to ensure any Work List Initiative – increased reporting sessions (WLI) sessions are reported on within 48 hours of allocation. Also, within day-to-day reporting sessions, all scans must be reported on and if there is a circumstance that would hinder this completion, escalation to the appropriate staff (ISM or DISM) must occur immediately.
The turnaround time is the length of time between the receiving the referral to the final authorisation of the report. It is reported as an average. Patients are categorised into 6 key areas;
Other – i.e. utilisation, DNA/cancellation rates etc.
5.1.1 The expected turnaround is described in the MSE Radiology Dashboard and is agreed at group radiology board following national recommendations and trust requirements.

Cancer performance data is collected and distributed weekly by the PACS Manager (or nominated deputy) which states the number of examinations and the average wait, further divided into request  vetting  scan  report authorisation.

5.2.1  Further  development  work  is  currently  being  undertaken  to  calculate  and  display turnaround times for Cancer, Urgent and Routine cases as a percentage within target. This will be included within the monthly MEHT site performance report.

Within the MEHT site performance report activity, demand and waiting time with an average turnaround are reported. As described above, this is to be further developed. The performance is discussed and recorded via MSE radiology board and MEHT accountability meetings.
Breach Management for Urgent Cancer Referrals

The radiology department has a specific process for pathway tracking for patients on an urgent 2 week wait for suspected cancer. Monitoring occurs on a daily basis. The pathway tracker will escalate issues with delay in vetting, capacity and escalation to the relevant lead for resolution.
Process for Monitoring Backlog and Risk Stratification

It  must  be  noted  that  should  the  backlog  reach  the  alert  criteria  for Urgent/Target requests, routine scan reporting will be lesser prioritised to allow for urgent/2WW scan reports to be completed  – this is due to the clinical indication for an urgent/2WW.

7.1.1 Further to this, high risk plain film chest, pelvis and spine reporting will be prioritised over other body parts due to the potential harm any delay may cause due  to  the  nature  of  pathology  likely  to  be  diagnosed  for  those  specific examinations.

It is the responsibility of the PACS/RSM manager to provide a weekly report to the Radiology Management Meeting and the Imaging Governance Meeting. This report must include:
The percentage of scans performed and reported on within the KPIs for each modality;
Average time (in working days) from request to examination and further from examination to report, broken down by each modality and vetting status (red, amber, green).
It is the responsibility of the Radiology Management Team to take action to mitigate the increased backlog and document within the weekly Radiology management minutes.

It is the Radiology Governance Lead's responsibility to provide a monthly report to the  Imaging  Governance  Meeting,  documenting  any  incidents  which  may  have occurred and lessons learned due the increased backlog.

In any cases which exceed the alert criteria and are found to have a significant or unexpected finding which could potentially impact on the quality of patient care. A Datix should be completed and harm review investigation undertaken including discussion with referring clinician regarding the degree of harm. If required this will then follow the Serious Incident / Duty of Candour route as per Trust policy.
